metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Trademark infringement and potential passing off by the respondent
Registration of the impugned trademark DORCO by the respondent no.1 without bona fide intention to use
Non-use of the registered trademark by the respondent no.1 for a continuous period of five years
Prior use and registration of the trademark DORCO by the petitioner
Validity of the registration of the impugned trademark under Sections 47, 57 and 125 of the Trademarks Act, 1999
Potential cancellation or removal of the impugned trademark from the register of trademarks
The petitioner's prior rights and reputation in the trademark DORCO in India and globally
The respondent no.1's potential bad faith in registering the impugned trademark
The effect of the respondent no.1's non-use of the trademark on the petitioner's business and goodwill
The application of the principles of honesty and fairness in the registration and use of trademarks
metadata.decision_summary:
**Background**

The case involves a trademark dispute between Dorco Co. Ltd. (petitioner) and Durga Enterprises (respondent no.1) over the trademark "DORCO" in respect of razors and razor blades in Class 8. The petitioner, a Korean company, has been using the trademark "DORCO" since 1964 and has registered it in India since 1994. The respondent no.1, an Indian partnership firm, obtained registration of the same trademark in 2003, claiming use since 2001.

**Legal Issues**

The petitioner filed a rectification petition under Sections 47, 57, and 125 of the Trademarks Act, 1999, seeking cancellation of the respondent no.1's trademark registration. The main issues in the case are:

1. **Non-use**: The petitioner claims that the respondent no.1 has not used the registered trademark for a continuous period of five years from the date of registration, making it liable for removal under Section 47(1)(b) of the Act.
2. **Collusion and malafide intention**: The petitioner alleges that the respondent no.1 obtained the registration in collusion with the petitioner's distributor in Nepal, with the intention of riding on the petitioner's goodwill, making it liable for rectification under Section 57(2) of the Act.

**Arguments**

The petitioner argued that it has been using the trademark "DORCO" globally since 1964 and in India since 1994, and has a strong reputation and goodwill associated with it. The respondent no.1's registration of the same trademark is an attempt to capitalize on the petitioner's reputation. The petitioner also submitted evidence of its use of the trademark in India, including sales data, invoices, and advertisements.

The respondent no.1, on the other hand, claimed that it has been using the trademark "DORCO" in India since 2001 and has a legitimate right to the registration.

**Court Findings**

The court observed that the respondent no.1 had not used the registered trademark for a continuous period of five years from the date of registration, as required under Section 47(1)(b) of the Act. The court also noted that the respondent no.1's partner, Govind Prasad Bagaria, was aware of the petitioner's rights and reputation in the trademark "DORCO" and had demanded a sum of Rs. 15,00,000/- to assign the trademark back to the petitioner.

**Decision**

Based on the evidence and arguments presented, the court ruled in favor of the petitioner, allowing the rectification petition and cancelling the respondent no.1's trademark registration. The court held that the respondent no.1's registration was liable for removal under Section 47(1)(b) of the Act due to non-use, and that the registration was also liable for rectification under Section 57(2) of the Act due to the respondent no.1's malafide intention to ride on the petitioner's goodwill. The court ordered the removal of the respondent no.1's trademark registration, allowing the petitioner to continue using its trademark "DORCO" in India.

metadata.full_text:
--- PAGE 1 ---
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 1 of 7 
 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
 
% 
 
 
 
                 Date of decision: 10th March, 2023 
 
+  
 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022 
 
 
DORCO CO. LTD. 
 
 
 
 
..... Petitioner 
Through: 
Ms. Priya Adlakha with Mrs. Bindra 
Rana and Ms. Rima Majumdar, 
Advocates. 
 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
DURGA ENTERPRISES AND ANR  
 
..... Respondents 
 
 
 
 
Through: 
Mr. 
Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, CGSC 
with Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, Mr. 
Sagar Mehlawat and  
Mr. Alexander Mathai Paikaday, 
Advocates for R-1. 
 
 
 
CORAM: 
 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMIT BANSAL 
 
 
 
 
 
JUDGMENT 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. (Oral) 
 
1. 
The present rectification petition has been filed on behalf of the 
petitioner seeking cancellation/removal of the trademark DORCO/ 
  bearing registration number 1252224 and registered in the 
name of respondent no.1 in respect of razors and razor blades in Class 8 
under Sections 47, 57 and 125 of the Trademarks Act, 1999 (hereinafter 
„Act‟).  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 2 of 7 
 
 
Case set up by the petitioner 
2. 
The case set up by the petitioner in the petition is as follows:  
2.1 
The petitioner, Dorco Co. Ltd., is engaged in the business of 
manufacturing and exporting grooming products such as shaving 
razors, blades, kitchen knives and stationery cutters since 1955. The 
petitioner is Asia's market leader in respect of razors, razor blades, 
kitchen knives and stationery cutters etc. The petitioner is widely 
recognized around the world for introducing the world‟s first 7-blade 
shaving system. The products of the petitioner are sold in 120 
countries around the world.  
2.2 
The petitioner derived the trademark DORCO from the name of its 
company, Dorco Co. Ltd., and has used the said trademark in different 
parts of the world since 1964 and in India since 1994. The petitioner 
is the registered proprietor of the trademark DORCO in India in 
various classes, since 1994 and obtained the first registration of the 
aforesaid trademark on 30th November, 1994 in India. Details of the 
registration of the trademarks of the petitioner are given on page 3 of 
the petition.  
2.3 
In 2015, the petitioner partnered with e-commerce platform „Lets 
Shave‟ to sell its products in India through www.letsshave.com. Since 
then, its products are available for sale on several e-commerce 
platforms in India such as, Amazon, Flipkart, Snapdeal, eBay etc. 
2.4 
The petitioner has also registered domain name www.dorco.in on 13th 
December, 2006, which comprises the petitioner‟s trademark 
DORCO.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 3 of 7 
 
2.5 
The petitioner has also been featured in popular trade magazines and 
newspapers with circulation in India. The petitioner has a strong 
presence on social networking sites such as Twitter, Instagram and 
Facebook. 
2.6 
The respondent no.1 is the partnership firm of one Mr Govind Prasad 
Bagaria and Ms. Rakhi Sureka.  The respondent no.1 got the 
trademark 
DORCO/ 
 
(hereinafter 
„impugned 
trademark‟) registered vide registration no.1252224 in respect of 
razors and razor blades in class 8 in India. The application for 
registration of the impugned trademark was filed on 28th November, 
2003 claiming use since 1st April, 2001.  
2.7 
The respondent no.1 has not used the registered trademark upto three 
months before the date of the present rectification petition, for a 
continuous period of five years from the date of registration, in 
relation to the goods for which the registration was granted. 
Therefore, it is liable to be removed for „non-use‟ in terms of Section 
47(1)(b) of the Act. 
2.8 
The registration of the impugned trademark is obtained by the 
respondent no.1 in collusion with the petitioner‟s distributor in Nepal, 
Mr. Pramod Sureka, with the dishonest and malafide intention to ride 
on the goodwill of the petitioner. Hence, the same is liable to be 
rectified under Sec 57 (2) of the Act. 
2.9 
Vide email dated 27th July, 2016, Mr. Pramod Sureka informed the 
petitioner that Govind Prasad Bagaria was well aware of the rights 
and reputation of the petitioner and its trademark DORCO and its 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 4 of 7 
 
formative marks. However, he demanded Rs. 15,00,000/- to assign the 
impugned trademark back to the petitioner. 
2.10 The partners of respondent no.1 have also applied for registration of 
the trademarks of other international brands such as “Anfanna” and 
“Tarzan Boy”. Hence, the partners of respondent no.1 are habitual 
trademark squatters and serial infringers. 
2.11 Accordingly, the present petition has been filed by the petitioner.  
Proceedings in the suit 
3. 
Notice in the present petition was issued by the Intellectual Property 
Appellate Board (IPAB) on 18th January, 2018. However, the respondent 
no.1 failed to appear before IPAB despite service. Thereafter, the present 
rectification got transferred to this Court after coming into effect of 
Tribunals Reforms Act, 2022 and the Court notice was issued to the 
respondent no.1 by this Court on 25th January, 2022. It is noted in the order 
dated 6th October, 2022 that the respondent no.1 refused to accept notice and 
that the same amounted to service.  
4. 
Subsequently, an application for substituted service was filed by the 
petitioner and the same was allowed and the respondent no.1 was directed to 
be served by way of publication. The affidavit of service has been filed on 
behalf of the petitioner and the same is taken on record. Therefore, the 
respondent no.1 is deemed to have been served. None has appeared on 
behalf of the respondent no.1, nor any reply/counter-statement has been filed 
on behalf of the respondent no.1. It is indicative of the fact that the 
respondent no.1 has nothing substantial to put forth on merits, by way of a 
response to the averments made in the petition.  
 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 5 of 7 
 
Analysis and Findings 
5. 
 I have heard the counsels for the parties and perused the record of the 
case.  
6. 
 In order to determine whether the trademark of the respondent no.1 is 
identical to the trademark of the petitioner, it would be apposite to refer to 
the two competing trademarks, as set out below:  
Petitoner‟s Trademarks 
Defendant‟s Trademarks 
 
 
7. 
The impugned trademark was applied for registration by the 
respondent no.1 claiming user since 1st April, 2001. However, upto a date of 
three months before filing the present rectification petition, a period of five 
years have elapsed from the date of registration of the impugned trademark, 
during which there has been no bonafide use of the impugned trademark in 
relation to the goods for which the registration was granted.  
8. 
In the judgment in Shell Transource Limited v. Shell International 
Petroleum Company Ltd.¸ 2012 SCC IPAB 29, it was observed by the 
IPAB that the onus of proving “non-user” is on the person who pleads the 
same. However, when the applicant pleads “non-user”, the respondent must 
specifically deny it. Therefore, in the absence of a specific denial, it was 
held that the allegations of “non-user” stood admitted.  
9. 
In the present case, the allegations of “non-user” against the 
respondent no.1 stand admitted in the absence of a specific denial of the 
same and the impugned trademark is liable to be removed from the Register 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 6 of 7 
 
of Trade Marks on account of “non-user” as contemplated under Section 
47(1)(b) of the Act.  
10. 
From the facts detailed above, it is clear that the petitioner is the 
proprietor of the impugned trademark. The respondent no.1 cannot claim to 
be the proprietor of the impugned trademark as there is nothing to show as 
to how the impugned trademark has been adopted by the respondent no.1. 
Therefore, the application for registration of the impugned trademark is in 
contravention of Section 18(1) of the Act. In fact, the registration of the 
petitioner‟s identical mark in respect of similar goods, was pending in India 
and was also cited as a conflicting mark in the examination report issued in 
the application for registration of the impugned trade mark. Therefore, as per 
Sections 9(1)(a) and 11(1)(a) of the Act, the registration of the impugned 
trademark could not be granted. 
11. 
The registration of the impugned trademark is also in contravention of 
Section 11(3)(b) of the Act, as its use would be prevented in India by virtue 
of the law of copyright, as the petitioner is the original owner of copyright in 
the impugned trademark, which is also registered as a trademark in its 
favour in Korea since 2002 and thereafter, in Turkey, China and Ukraine. 
12. 
The grant of registration of the impugned trademark by the respondent 
no.2 is against the principles of Section 11(3)(a) of the Act, as there is no 
dispute that the petitioner is the prior user of the impugned trademark since 
1994 in India and across the world since 1964. Due to such a long, 
continuous and extensive use, the impugned trademark is solely associated 
with the petitioner. Therefore, the registration of the impugned trademark 
should have been refused by the respondent no.2. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 7 of 7 
 
13. 
In view of the discussion above, it is clear that the impugned 
trademark has been adopted by the respondent no.1 dishonestly to trade 
upon the established goodwill and reputation of the petitioner and to project 
itself to be associated with the petitioner. The nature of the impugned 
trademark is such that it will deceive the public and create confusion as 
regards the source of the goods manufactured and sold under the impugned 
trademark.  
14. 
Accordingly, the present petition is allowed and the impugned 
trademark registered under trademark application no.1252224 in the name of 
the respondent no.1 in Class 8 is removed from the Register of Trade Marks.  
15. 
 A copy of the order be sent to the respondents through e-mail. The 
Registry is directed to supply a copy of the present order to the Trademark 
Registry, at e-mail - llc-ipo@gov.in for compliance.  
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. 
MARCH 10, 2023 
at 
 
 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Dorco vs Durga.pdf", a legal proceeding was held in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi, with case number C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022 and 2023/DHC/001821. The petitioner, Dorco Co. Ltd., sought to cancel the trademark "DORCO" registered by respondent Durga Enterprises. 

The petitioner, represented by Ms. Priya Adlakha and others, claimed to have used the trademark "DORCO" since 1964 and obtained registration in India in 1994. They argued that their products, including razors and razor blades, are sold in 120 countries and are widely recognized.

The respondent, represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar and others, held the registration number 1252224 for the trademark "DORCO" in respect of razors and razor blades in Class 8. 

The court, presided by Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal, heard the petition on March 10, 2023. The judgment, digitally signed on March 14, 2023, is based on the Trademarks Act, 1999, specifically Sections 47, 57, and 125. The case details the petitioner's history, their use of the trademark, and their registration in various classes. 

Source: Dorco vs Durga.pdf, Pages 1-2 of 7.

Ltd. against Durga Enterprises and another respondent. The petition seeks cancellation of the trademark "DORCO" (registration number 1252224) registered in the name of Durga Enterprises for razors and razor blades in Class 8. The petition was filed under Sections 47, 57, and 125 of the Trademarks Act, 1999. The case was heard by Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal, with the decision dated March 10, 2023. The petitioner was represented by Ms. Priya Adlakha and others, while the respondent was represented by Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar and others. (Source: 6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf, page 1 of 7)

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
According to the provided PDF document, "Dorco vs Durga.pdf," a legal proceeding is underway in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi (Case No. 2023/DHC/001821, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022). The petitioner, Dorco Co. Ltd., is represented by advocates Ms. Priya Adlakha, Mrs. Bindra Rana, and Ms. Rima Majumdar. The respondents are Durga Enterprises and another party, represented by Mr. Harish.

The background and facts of the case reveal that the petitioner, Dorco, has a strong presence in India and globally, with features in trade magazines and newspapers, as well as social media platforms. The respondent, Durga Enterprises, is a partnership firm that registered the trademark "DORCO" in India for razors and razor blades in class 8, with registration no. 1252224. However, the respondent has not used the trademark for a continuous period of five years from the date of registration, making it liable for removal due to non-use under Section 47(1)(b) of the Act.

The petitioner argues that the registration of the impugned trademark was obtained with dishonest and malafide intention to ride on the goodwill of Dorco, in collusion with the petitioner's distributor in Nepal, Mr. Pramod Sureka. The petitioner seeks rectification under Section 57(2) of the Act. The case was decided on March 10, 2023, as per the provided PDF document.

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary: According to page 3 of the PDF "6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf", the petitioner, Dorco Co. Ltd., has a strong presence on social media and has been featured in trade magazines and newspapers in India. The respondent, Durga Enterprises, registered the trademark "DORCO" in 2003 for razors and razor blades in India, but has not used it for five years. The petitioner claims the registration was obtained with malafide intention to ride on their goodwill. The respondent's distributor in Nepal, Mr. Pramod Sureka, informed the petitioner that Govind Prasad Bagaria was aware of the petitioner's rights and reputation. The case is being heard in the High Court of Delhi, with the petitioner seeking rectification under Section 57(2) of the Act due to non-use and malafide intention. The case number is C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022.

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf", the legal proceedings in the case of Dorco Co. Ltd. vs Durga Enterprises and Anr (2023/DHC/001821) involve a trademark dispute. The petitioner, Dorco Co. Ltd., filed a petition against the respondent, Durga Enterprises, for trademark infringement and non-use. The respondent had applied for registration of the impugned trademark, but the petitioner claimed that it was not being used bona fide.

The proceedings began with a notice issued by the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) on January 18, 2018, which was later transferred to the High Court of Delhi after the Tribunals Reforms Act, 2022, came into effect. The respondent failed to appear despite service, and the court deemed them served after an application for substituted service was allowed.

The petitioner argued that the respondent was a habitual trademark squatter and serial infringer, having applied for registration of other international brands. The respondent demanded Rs. 15,00,000 to assign the impugned trademark back to the petitioner. The court analyzed the competing trademarks and found that the respondent had not used the impugned trademark for five years, making it liable for removal from the Register of Trade Marks under Section 47(1)(b) of the Act.

The court's decision, dated March 10, 2023, was based on the absence of a specific denial by the respondent of the allegations of non-use, which stood admitted. The petitioner was deemed the proprietor of the impugned trademark, and the respondent's claim was rejected. (Source: "6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf", pages 1-7)

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary: According to page 4 of the PDF "6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf", the respondent, Durga Enterprises, demanded Rs. 15,00,000 to assign the impugned trademark back to the petitioner, Dorco Co. Ltd. The partners of Durga Enterprises are alleged to be habitual trademark squatters and serial infringers, having applied for registration of other international brands. The petition was filed, and notice was issued by the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) on January 18, 2018. The respondent failed to appear, and the case was transferred to the High Court of Delhi after the Tribunals Reforms Act, 2022 came into effect. The court issued notice on January 25, 2022, which the respondent refused to accept, deemed as service. No response or reply was filed by the respondent, indicating a lack of substantial defense. (Source: 6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf, 2023/DHC/001821, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022)

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary: According to page 5 of the PDF "6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf", the High Court of Delhi analyzed the trademark case between Dorco Co. Ltd. and Durga Enterprises. The respondent's trademark was applied for registration in 2001, but there was no bonafide use of the trademark for five years after registration. The court cited the judgment in Shell Transource Limited v. Shell International Petroleum Company Ltd. (2012), which states that the onus of proving "non-user" is on the person who pleads it. Since the respondent did not specifically deny the allegations of "non-user", the allegations stand admitted, and the impugned trademark is liable to be removed from the Register. The decision was made on March 10, 2023, in the case C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022. (Source: 6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf, page 5)
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 5 of 7 
 
Analysis and Findings 
5. 
 I have heard the counsels for the parties and perused the record of the 
case.  
6. 
 In order to determine whether the trademark of the respondent no.1 is 
identical to the trademark of the petitioner, it would be apposite to refer to 
the two competing trademarks, as set out below:  
Petitoner‟s Trademarks 
Defendant‟s Trademarks 
 
 
7. 
The impugned trademark was applied for registration by the 
respondent no.1 claiming user since 1st April, 2001. However, upto a date of 
three months before filing the present rectification petition, a period of five 
years have elapsed from the date of registration of the impugned trademark, 
during which there has been no bonafide use of the impugned trademark in 
relation to the goods for which the registration was granted.  
8. 
In the judgment in Shell Transource Limited v. Shell International 
Petroleum Company Ltd.¸ 2012 SCC IPAB 29, it was observed by the 
IPAB that the onus of proving “non-user” is on the person who pleads the 
same. However, when the applicant pleads “non-user”, the respondent must 
specifically deny it. Therefore, in the absence of a specific denial, it was 
held that the allegations of “non-user” stood admitted.  
9. 
In the present case, the allegations of “non-user” against the 
respondent no.1 stand admitted in the absence of a specific denial of the 
same and the impugned trademark is liable to be removed from the Register 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary: According to page 6 of the PDF "6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf", the petitioner, Dorco Co. Ltd., is the proprietor of the impugned trademark. The respondent, Durga Enterprises, cannot claim ownership as there is no evidence of adoption. The registration of the impugned trademark is in contravention of Sections 18(1), 9(1)(a), and 11(1)(a) of the Act. The petitioner has been using the trademark since 1994 in India and globally since 1964, making it solely associated with them. The registration of the impugned trademark by the respondent no.2 (likely a registrar) is against the principles of Section 11(3)(a) of the Act. The case, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022, was decided on March 10, 2023. The petitioner is represented by Ms. Priya Adlakha, Mrs. Bindra Rana, and Ms. Rima Majumdar, while the respondent is represented by Mr. Harish. (Source: 6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf, page 6)
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 6 of 7 
 
of Trade Marks on account of “non-user” as contemplated under Section 
47(1)(b) of the Act.  
10. 
From the facts detailed above, it is clear that the petitioner is the 
proprietor of the impugned trademark. The respondent no.1 cannot claim to 
be the proprietor of the impugned trademark as there is nothing to show as 
to how the impugned trademark has been adopted by the respondent no.1. 
Therefore, the application for registration of the impugned trademark is in 
contravention of Section 18(1) of the Act. In fact, the registration of the 
petitioner‟s identical mark in respect of similar goods, was pending in India 
and was also cited as a conflicting mark in the examination report issued in 
the application for registration of the impugned trade mark. Therefore, as per 
Sections 9(1)(a) and 11(1)(a) of the Act, the registration of the impugned 
trademark could not be granted. 
11. 
The registration of the impugned trademark is also in contravention of 
Section 11(3)(b) of the Act, as its use would be prevented in India by virtue 
of the law of copyright, as the petitioner is the original owner of copyright in 
the impugned trademark, which is also registered as a trademark in its 
favour in Korea since 2002 and thereafter, in Turkey, China and Ukraine. 
12. 
The grant of registration of the impugned trademark by the respondent 
no.2 is against the principles of Section 11(3)(a) of the Act, as there is no 
dispute that the petitioner is the prior user of the impugned trademark since 
1994 in India and across the world since 1964. Due to such a long, 
continuous and extensive use, the impugned trademark is solely associated 
with the petitioner. Therefore, the registration of the impugned trademark 
should have been refused by the respondent no.2. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:14.03.2023 15:05:52
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Dorco vs Durga.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi made a decision on March 10, 2023, in the case of Dorco Co. Ltd. vs Durga Enterprises and Anr (2023/DHC/001821, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022). The petitioner, Dorco Co. Ltd., was represented by Ms. Priya Adlakha, Mrs. Bindra Rana, and Ms. Rima Majumdar, while the respondent, Durga Enterprises, was represented by Mr. Harish.

The court decision stated that the respondent had adopted the impugned trademark dishonestly to trade on the established goodwill and reputation of the petitioner, and to create confusion among the public regarding the source of goods manufactured and sold under the impugned trademark. The court found that the nature of the impugned trademark was such that it would deceive the public and create confusion.

As a result, the court allowed the petition and ordered the removal of the impugned trademark, registered under trademark application no. 1252224 in the name of the respondent in Class 8, from the Register of Trade Marks. A copy of the order was directed to be sent to the respondents via email, and the Registry was instructed to supply a copy of the order to the Trademark Registry for compliance. The decision was made by Amit Bansal, J., on March 10, 2023, as stated in the PDF source.

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary: According to page 7 of the PDF "6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf", the High Court of Delhi ruled in favor of the petitioner, Dorco Co. Ltd., in a trademark dispute against Durga Enterprises and another respondent. The court found that the respondent's trademark was adopted dishonestly to trade on Dorco's goodwill and reputation, and would deceive the public and create confusion. As a result, the court allowed the petition and removed the impugned trademark (application no. 1252224) from the Register of Trade Marks. The order was signed by Judge Amit Bansal on March 10, 2023. A copy of the order was directed to be sent to the respondents and the Trademark Registry for compliance. (Source: 6. Dorco vs Durga.pdf, page 7)
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001821 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 50/2022                                              
 
 
  Page 7 of 7 
 
13. 
In view of the discussion above, it is clear that the impugned 
trademark has been adopted by the respondent no.1 dishonestly to trade 
upon the established goodwill and reputation of the petitioner and to project 
itself to be associated with the petitioner. The nature of the impugned 
trademark is such that it will deceive the public and create confusion as 
regards the source of the goods manufactured and sold under the impugned 
trademark.  
14. 
Accordingly, the present petition is allowed and the impugned 
trademark registered under trademark application no.1252224 in the name of 
the respondent no.1 in Class 8 is removed from the Register of Trade Marks.  
15. 
 A copy of the order be sent to the respondents through e-mail. The 
Registry is directed to supply a copy of the present order to the Trademark 
Registry, at e-mail - llc-ipo@gov.in for compliance.  
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. 
MARCH 10, 2023 
at
